The pandemic was panic inducing to us TheaterMakers for so many reasons.  I can’t tell you how many times throughout those two years I was petrified.  What would I do if the theater never recovered?  The theater isn’t only my profession, it’s my hobby, the thing I do for fun.  How would I survive if it was gone? 

We got through that by putting our heads down and staying focused, and pivoting like a power forward for the Knicks. 

But now . . . when coming back, there can be a different panic.  And over the past year, I’ve felt it, and I’m sure you have too.  That, “Whoa, I haven’t done this in awhile,” or, “What if it goes away again,” or that feeling that the stakes are higher than ever.

I’ve spoken to a lot of TheaterMakers about this - writers, directors, actors and more and we’ve all felt it.

So, here’s what to remember:

1️⃣ It’s ok to have anxiety about getting back into that rehearsal room, on that stage, or just opening up that computer to write again.

2️⃣ Reach out to others and talk about how you’re feeling - because you’re not alone.

3️⃣ I found the best way through it was, ironically, to make more theater - because nothing will make you feel better than getting in that room with people and collaborating on something brand new.

We’re STILL all in this together and I believe the theater and all its theatermakers will be stronger than ever as a result.

#TheaterMaker #BroadwayProducer #TheProducersPerspective #PanicAttacks #MentalHealth

Years ago, someone told me . . . "Ken, you're not a writer.  You're a producer." 

And then this past summer, despite the shows and things I've written, someone said the same thing.

I was confused.  Don't I decide what I am?  And why can't I be both.

Oh wait.  I can. 

(The irony is, I was a writer long before I was a producer - and only started producing to get my work out into the world - and I liked it so I kept doing it!)

You can too. 

I'm proud of to sit at the Author table during my JOY tech.  And I'm proud to sit at the Producer table for A Beautiful Noise. And hey - I may want to design the costumes on something I haven't even come up with yet. (Ok, that's probably not going to happen, but you get the idea.)

You decide who you are and what you want to do and what you want to be.  End of story and end of post. 

#JoyMusical #JoyTheMusical #NewMusical #GeorgeStreetPlayhouse

And if you’re a TheaterMaker who faces an obstacle on your journey . . . first, yeah, it’s ok to say a few choice words to get your frustration.  As long as you get back to work.

He is home.

After a ceremony on the steps in front of the Ganges led by a Puja (Indian Priest), who walked and talked me through a blessing of the ashes, I was taken by boat to the middle of the river.  And there, I was finally able to return my father back to the place of his birth - a place he left so he could find a better life and help out his family who stayed. 

He was happy he found a home in the US.  But I think he always felt guilty about leaving his Mother, his Brother, his Aunties and more. 

Well, now, you’re finally home, my father and friend.  Nestled in the arms of those spiritual waters.  Be at peace. 

#drkenny #gangesriver #india #varanasi

This year marks my 30th anniversary on Broadway.

In 1993, I got my first job on Broadway as a production assistant on the Broadway revival of My Fair Lady starring Richard Chamberlain and @melissa_errico_fairymom. 

It opened my eyes to all the other people and positions that are needed to produce a Broadway show. Instantly, I knew acting was a temporary stop on my journey as a theatermaker.

Honestly can't believe it's been 30 years. But there's no stopping now!

Some continuing education on international production thanks to the @broadwayleague.  I learned from my Dad that you should always be learning. 

And the international market has exploded over the last few years, giving us another opportunity to mitigate risk for our investors and increase exposure and income for our authors and creatives. (We’re catching up with the film world.)

A few things I picked up from the session:
1️⃣ If you have a brand with international potential (not everything does), make your international deals when you make your Broadway deals.
2️⃣ There’s a big difference between replica and non-replica productions. Something’s the market will dictate what will work better.
3️⃣ Picking an international partner shouldn’t be done over zoom. Get on a plane and meet people face to face, see their shows, visit the theaters.

Thanks to Dan Hinde, Seth Stuhl, and Dan Watkins for sharing their wisdom! And Alecia Parker for facilitating the conversation!

This non-descript room in a bland corporate building in Hackensack, NJ is one of my favorite rooms to be in. 

Because it’s a focus group about Broadway. 

Those are REAL audience members behind that smoked glass.  And my marketing team and I are listening to what they really think and what they really want from their Broadway experiences on and off the stage.

I’ll summarize my key takeaways from this group in an article on kendavenport.com in a few weeks, but every time I do this I’m reminded that what we think we know is never what we really know, until we listen to our actual audience members.

They are the boss.

More soon.

I spend the majority of my time on three things. That’s it. A lot different than when I was younger and ran around trying to do everything.  Those three things in order of priority are:
1️⃣ Family
2️⃣ Theater
3️⃣ Golf

They all give me so much joy, love, and fulfillment.  And they all can be hard too!  But what worth doing isn’t.

Well, I was able to achieve one of my goals for #3 recently when I freakin’ won my golf club’s net championship! (I set my goal to win a club championship before I was even a member of a club!) 

And I thought I’d share - mostly to thank the three teachers that helped me with my obsession since I picked up the game 10 years ago. 

Because without teachers in anything we are nothing:  the staff at @fiveirongolf, the late Bill Madonna, Adam Kolloff, and my current coach, the guru who is Mike Bender.  He made this happen. Oh and he likes Broadway, so . . .

Lastly, thanks to my wife - who understands that we all need a hobby - something aside from the other two priorities, because it makes me even better at those first two things. (Oh and she plays too and can outdrive me.)

And now, I guess it’s time for a new goal!

Remember that time a few weeks ago when I won that golf tournament?  Well, I was in another one! This time?  Came in last.  Oh well! 

Golf is like theater, which is like life . .  Wins, losses, hits, misses, ups, downs, sideways and upside downs.  Gotta have em all or it wouldn’t be worth doing. 

And here’s what I do when something doesn’t go my way that I recommend:  I sit down and ask myself, “What could I have done differently?” Then I write down the answers (helps you remember it more). 

And then I ask other people smarter than me the same thing.

That way the learning makes everything you do a win, no matter the outcome.

Took in @rockrollmanshow again and had a terrific time.  How could you not with those tunes and this cast!  Congrats to the entire cast and super talented multi-hyphenate bookwriter and producer @rosecaiola.

A few weeks ago, I wrote an article about adjusting the performance schedule this month to meet the audience's new (post-pandemic) needs.

As an industry, we rarely mix our schedule up . . . and what happens is that these times were set for a different audience in a different decade! Is it time to shake it up now?

We are!

Starting this month, @abeautifulnoisemusical is going to have FOUR matinees per week. 50% of our performances will be matinees. So we'll have 2pm shows on Wednesdays, Saturdays, Sundays, and now THURSDAYS! 

And we'll be the only Broadway show with Thursday matinees. (Until @harmonyanewmusical starts 😉)

In coming up with these results, I looked at the data for the Thursday matinees in September (our first month - and notoriously a difficult month for Broadway). I compared them to the averages for the Wednesday evening performances during the previous 12 weeks. 

Why Wednesday evening?  This is the performance that we cut in exchange for the Thursday matinee.  This change wasn’t just about adding a performance that I believed my audience wanted . . . but it was about eliminating a performance that they didn’t.

Cleaning out my storage unit and just found these.

Here is just a small collection of inquiries I made into the rights to a whole bunch of titles, dating back to 2001 (!) when I was dreaming of creating and producing musicals. I tried to get the rights to everything from:
👉 Stealing Home
👉 Chances Are
👉 Buffy The Vampire Slayer
👉 Ordinary People
👉 The Blue and the Gray
👉 Grease 2
👉 And so many more.

I got rejections from every one - if I even got a response at all.

I don’t know why I kept them all these 22 years later. Maybe so I could share them with you.  So you could see that it takes 100 no's or even no responses, to get to where you want to go.

So keep asking.

Sometimes your life and career take you places where you never imagined you’d be . . . like the 3rd row of @usher’s last show at @parkmgm in Las Vegas. 

And you’re surrounded by 5,200 people losing their mind.  And you can understand why, because this is a man who . . .
1️⃣ Was given a gift to do what he does.
2️⃣ Works his you-know-what off to make sure that gift doesn’t go to waste.
3️⃣ Uses that gift to unite an audience through entertainment. 

And then after the show you find yourself backstage in a place where it’s way too cool to take pictures.  But it’s filled with a vibrancy for making music and spreading love that you’ve never witnessed before.

Oh - and boy could Broadway learn a few things from the show itself . . . a show that included him IN every section of the audience, roller skating, giant scenery and also incredible intimacy.  At one point,  I almost whipped out my notebook and started taking notes. But, I’m already not the coolest guy around so . . .

But here are a few I took in my mind . . .
1️⃣ Warm up an audience in some way.
2️⃣ What fourth wall?
3️⃣ Save the best and the biggest for last.

(Oh and this performance was the company’s “closing night” in Vegas after their sold out 100 shows. The clip of his dancers surrounding him is my fave - reminded me of the same emotions us Broadway folks go through when we drop the curtain for the final time.  See and feel the emotion as he (tries) to say goodnight)

I got invited to participate in a think tank workshop at @columbia_biz to discuss . . . The Future of New York City Real Estate.

Other folks in the group?  A state senator, real estate professors, a Ph.D., bank presidents, CEOs of real estate firms.  And me.  And my heavy duty dose of imposter syndrome.

But I spoke up anyway.  My idea?  Fill the vacant storefronts by giving low rent deals to nonprofit theater companies.  Like Chicago.  Start the New York Storefront Theater movement.

Because what attracts people to New York are things that you can’t get anywhere else. Live entertainment from the best theatermakers in the world is it!

(Disclaimer - I might be biased.)

Thanks for having me. I was overwhelmed by the smarts in the room and honored to participate.

#Speaking #Producer #RealEstate #NewYorkCity

Eight years ago last week, before the covid-induced streaming revolution, we livestreamed a performance of the Off-Broadway production of #DaddyLongLegs with @menguinmcg and @adamhalpin. The headline from this 2015 @playbill article says it all: people tuned in!

Here are more stats we collected post-livestream:
👍 99.5 percent of viewers want more Broadway and Off-Broadway shows streamed in the future
👍 82.2 percent of viewers said they'd pay to watch a live stream of a Broadway or Off-Broadway show
👍 40.3 percent of viewers had not heard about Daddy Long Legs before the event
👍 Cast album sales increased by 484%

. . . and to think, this data was collected back in 2015!!! 

And since then there has been a massive increase in the number of licensed productions around the world! 

It was a hit for us . . . if we could figure out a way to make it more economically feasible, it could be a hit for ALL shows. 

Did you miss it?  Check it out on @broadwayhd.

On February 4th, @harmonyanewmusical will end its Broadway run.

Stories like Harmony need to be told.  And I am so proud of its Authors, @barrymanilowofficial and @brucehsussman, who never gave up in demanding that this story be on Broadway. To @warrencarlyle - who took a script and a score and made it into a SHOW.  You do what great Directors do - imagine things we could never have imagined.

And to the incredible cast and crew, including Chip Zien, @officialsierraboggess, @jujujuliebee, @ladysemmes, @0shanick and those incredible Harmonists, @seanbell13, @dannykornfeld, @thezalowen, @ericfromminnesota, @itsblakeroman, @steven_telsey, who told and sang that story better than we ever could have imagined while we zoomed about it during the pandemic.  And to my partners, @sandi.moran and Garry Kief, and the incredibly courageous co-producers and investors who are the ones who made it possible - thank you for making sure that this story was told.  Without your passion for the arts and for this story, Harmony would not have happened.

If you haven't seen Harmony yet, rush to the Barrymore.  You only have 24 chances left (including tonight). If you miss it, well, it'll be one of those shows ten years from now that you'll regret not seeing.  I promise you that.
